Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Leading the daily prayers in the mosque
Situation2: The regular backup is away, so most congregants expect him to step forward for the scheduled prayer.
Story: Tonight is the only evening this week that Amir and I can be together. He’s been looking forward to it, and so have I—just a quiet dinner, maybe a walk, a chance to talk without glancing at the clock. But as I’m getting ready, my phone buzzes. The mosque committee reminds me that the regular backup imam is out of town, and everyone expects me to lead the evening prayer. I know how much the congregation relies on me, especially when there’s no one else. My heart sinks. Amir’s face lights up when I arrive, but I can’t shake the weight pressing on my chest. I want to be present, to laugh and listen, but my mind keeps drifting to the mosque, to the people waiting for guidance and comfort. I feel torn in two—one part longing to be the girlfriend Amir needs tonight, the other pulled by my duty as imam. The minutes tick by, and I can’t ignore the growing tension inside me, knowing that whatever I choose, someone will be disappointed.
